title: 105_hr4093
content: The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It establishes a standard relating to hospital lengths of stay for group health plans under the Public Health Service Act. The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" requires group health plans to provide inpatient coverage for a medically appropriate period determined by a physician. It prohibits denying eligibility based on coverage requirements. The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" prohibits penalizing providers for following the coverage requirements, incentivizing shorter inpatient stays, or requiring preauthorization for length of stay determination. An appeals process and penalties will be established by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Labor. The Secretary of Labor will establish an appeals process and penalties for plans or issuers that violate the provisions of this section. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements as if they applied to such plan. The Act is amended to include sections 2704 and 2706. Amendments are made to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 713. STANDARDS FOR HOSPITAL LENGTHS OF STAY. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must provide inpatient coverage for a medically appropriate period determined by a physician in consultation with the patient. They are prohibited from denying eligibility based on coverage requirements to avoid minimum standards. The curr_chunk discusses penalties for providers who do not comply with inpatient coverage requirements, including restrictions on reimbursement and incentives to reduce patient stays. An appeals process and penalties will be established by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish an appeals process and penalties for plans or issuers that violate the provisions of the section. The requirements of this section will be treated as a material modification in the terms of the plan for notice purposes. The section requires that the last sentence of section 104(b)(1) be provided within 60 days after the first plan year in which the requirements apply. Conforming and clerical amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. The table of contents is also amended to include a new item after section 712. "Sec. 713. Standard for hospital lengths of stay. Individual Health Insurance - Subpart 3 of part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act is amended by adding a new section: SEC. 2752. STANDARDS FOR HOSPITAL LENGTHS OF STAY." The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to those for group health plans. The amendments to the group health plan regulations under the Affordable Care Act will apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1999. This includes a special rule for group health plans maintained through collective bargaining agreements. The amendments made by subsections regarding group health plan regulations under the Affordable Care Act will not apply to plan years before the termination of collective bargaining agreements or January 1, 1999. The amendments made by subsections regarding group health plan regulations under the Affordable Care Act will not apply to plan years before the termination of collective bargaining agreements or January 1, 1999. Any plan amendment made pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement solely to conform to new requirements added by the subsections shall not be considered a termination of the agreement. Individual market amendments will apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market on or after January 1, 1999. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended to coordinate regulations with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, the Public Health Service Act, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
